relation_surface: in steels
rel_desc: Hydrogen Induced Cracking (HIC) is described as a cracking mechanism that occurs in steels, which plausibly includes low alloy steels as a subset.
resolution_context: Text states that the link-up of cracks occurs on different planes in steels; low alloy steel is a type of steel mentioned in the same definitional context.
justification: The chunk explains HIC as stepwise internal cracks linking hydrogen blisters "in the metal" and later notes this link-up "in steels". Low alloy steel is defined in the same section as a family of steels, so HIC can reasonably be inferred to occur in low alloy steels, though this is not explicitly stated.
remark: Relation added mainly to capture that HIC is a cracking mechanism relevant to steels, with low alloy steel treated as a representative steel family. Semantics somewhat generic; confidence reduced because the text does not explicitly name low alloy steels as HIC-susceptible.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: on different planes in the metal / steels; may connect to the metal surface
qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: no externally applied stress is needed for formation of HIC
qualifiers.CausalHint: because of internal pressure resulting from the accumulation of hydrogen
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CrackMechanism: stepwise internal cracks that connect adjacent hydrogen blisters; LinkMechanism: transgranular plastic shear

evidence_excerpt: The link-up of these cracks on different planes in steels has been referred to as stepwise cracking to characterize the nature of the crack appearance.
canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a structure, phase, feature, or process is present in or takes place within a given material or material class.
remarks: Relation added mainly to capture that HIC is a cracking mechanism relevant to steels, with low alloy steel treated as a representative steel family. Semantics somewhat generic; confidence reduced because the text does not explicitly name low alloy steels as HIC-susceptible.

relation_surface: This decomposition is known as graphitization
rel_desc: Graphitization corresponds to decomposition of carbide phases into graphite nodules, effectively producing graphite nodules in the steel.
resolution_context: The text equates graphitization with decomposition of carbides into graphite nodules; modeled as process producing nodules.
justification: At elevated temperatures, carbide phases decompose into graphite nodules, and this decomposition is known as graphitization, linking the process to the nodules.
remark: Carbide phases are not an explicit entity; relation framed between graphitization and graphite nodules to preserve transformation context.
evidence_excerpt: At elevated temperatures, the carbide phases in these steels are unstable and may decompose into graphite nodules. This decomposition is known as graphitization.
canonical_rel_desc: A process or entity generates or leads to the formation of a product, feature, or outcome.
remarks: Carbide phases are not an explicit entity; relation framed between graphitization and graphite nodules to preserve transformation context.
